--- Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> I had been thinking about adding in extra types of
> mutation e.g. remove 
> connection/node, but not using them in the main
> search. Instead I was 
> thinking of periodically trimming back the
> population's complexity by 
> only allowing these types of mutation (deletion) and
> running the search 
> algorithm as normal, this should work because the
> search is elitist and 
> therefore we will never loose the good networks we
> have evolved so far. 
> I was initially intending to do this to trim back
> unecessary clutter in 
> good networks prior to performing any visualization,
> but I think it may 
> be useful as part of the search itself.

Philip and I are working on a late-breaking paper for
the GECCO conference on this very subject.

Per your approach, I've seen some use in the
literature of networks trained with backprop then
being pruned with a GA, and there have been at least a
couple of neuroevolutionary techniques (including
Yao's EPNet) that use additive and subtractive
mutations in the search.

Not to jump the gun on conclusions yet (we're in the
middle of running experiments), but it seems that
including subtractive mutations in the search makes
for a slightly less efficient search, but
significantly more efficient solutions.

As others have done, we'll post the paper once it's
complete and on its way to GECCO, probably mid-May.

Derek
